segment.source: This document describes the fundamental characteristics of the Marble Maze project, for example, how it uses Visual C++ in the Windows Runtime environment, how it is created and structured, and how it is built.
segment.target: This document describes the fundamental characteristics of the Marble Maze project, for example, how it uses Visual C++ in the Windows Runtime environment, how it is created and structured, and how it is built.

segment.source: The document also describes several of the conventions that are used in the code.
segment.target: The document also describes several of the conventions that are used in the code.

segment.source: Note The sample code that corresponds to this document is found in the DirectX Marble Maze game sample.
segment.target: Note The sample code that corresponds to this document is found in the DirectX Marble Maze game sample.

segment.source: Here are some of the key points that this document discusses for when you plan and develop your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game.
segment.target: Here are some of the key points that this document discusses for when you plan and develop your Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game.

segment.source: Use the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template in a C++ application to create your DirectX UWP game.
segment.target: Use the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template in a C++ application to create your DirectX UWP game.

segment.source: Use Visual Studio to build a UWP app project as you would build a standard project.
segment.target: Use Visual Studio to build a UWP app project as you would build a standard project.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime provides classes and interfaces so that you can develop UWP apps in a more modern, object-oriented manner.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime provides classes and interfaces so that you can develop UWP apps in a more modern, object-oriented manner.

segment.source: Use object references with the hat (^) symbol to manage the lifetime of Windows Runtime variables, Microsoft::WRL::ComPtr to manage the lifetime of COM objects, and std::shared\_ptr or std::unique\_ptr to manage the lifetime of all other heap-allocated C++ objects.
segment.target: Use object references with the hat (^) symbol to manage the lifetime of Windows Runtime variables, Microsoft::WRL::ComPtr to manage the lifetime of COM objects, and std::shared\_ptr or std::unique\_ptr to manage the lifetime of all other heap-allocated C++ objects.

segment.source: In most cases, use exception handling, instead of result codes, to deal with unexpected errors.
segment.target: In most cases, use exception handling, instead of result codes, to deal with unexpected errors.

segment.source: Use SAL annotations together with code analysis tools to help discover errors in your app.
segment.target: Use SAL annotations together with code analysis tools to help discover errors in your app.

segment.source: Creating the Visual Studio project
segment.target: Creating the Visual Studio project

segment.source: If you've downloaded and extracted the sample, you can open the MarbleMaze.sln solution file in Visual Studio, and you'll have the code in front of you.
segment.target: If you've downloaded and extracted the sample, you can open the MarbleMaze.sln solution file in Visual Studio, and you'll have the code in front of you.

segment.source: You can also view the source on the DirectX Marble Maze game sample MSDN Samples Gallery page by selecting the Browse Code tab.
segment.target: You can also view the source on the DirectX Marble Maze game sample MSDN Samples Gallery page by selecting the Browse Code tab.

segment.source: When we created the Visual Studio project for Marble Maze, we started with an existing project.
segment.target: When we created the Visual Studio project for Marble Maze, we started with an existing project.

segment.source: However, if you do not already have an existing project that provides the basic functionality that your DirectX UWP game requires, we recommend that you create a project based on the Visual Studio DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template because it provides a basic working 3-D application.
segment.target: However, if you do not already have an existing project that provides the basic functionality that your DirectX UWP game requires, we recommend that you create a project based on the Visual Studio DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template because it provides a basic working 3-D application.

segment.source: One important project setting in the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template is the /ZW option, which enables the program to use the Windows Runtime language extensions.
segment.target: One important project setting in the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template is the /ZW option, which enables the program to use the Windows Runtime language extensions.

segment.source: This option is enabled by default when you use the Visual Studio template.
segment.target: This option is enabled by default when you use the Visual Studio template.

segment.source: Caution The /ZW option is not compatible with options such as /clr.In the case of /clr, this means that you cannot target both the .NET Framework and the Windows Runtime from the same Visual C++ project.
segment.target: Caution The /ZW option is not compatible with options such as /clr.In the case of /clr, this means that you cannot target both the .NET Framework and the Windows Runtime from the same Visual C++ project.

segment.source: Every UWP app that you acquire from the Windows Store comes in the form of an app package.
segment.target: Every UWP app that you acquire from the Windows Store comes in the form of an app package.

segment.source: An app package contains a package manifest, which contains information about your app.
segment.target: An app package contains a package manifest, which contains information about your app.

segment.source: For example, you can specify the capabilities (that is, the required access to protected system resources or user data) of your app.
segment.target: For example, you can specify the capabilities (that is, the required access to protected system resources or user data) of your app.

segment.source: If you determine that your app requires certain capabilities, use the package manifest to declare the required capabilities.
segment.target: If you determine that your app requires certain capabilities, use the package manifest to declare the required capabilities.

segment.source: The manifest also lets you specify project properties such as supported device rotations, tile images, and the splash screen.
segment.target: The manifest also lets you specify project properties such as supported device rotations, tile images, and the splash screen.

segment.source: For more info about app packages, see Packaging apps.
segment.target: For more info about app packages, see Packaging apps.

segment.source: Building, deploying, and running the game
segment.target: Building, deploying, and running the game

segment.source: Build a UWP app project as you would build a standard project.
segment.target: Build a UWP app project as you would build a standard project.

segment.source: (On the menu bar, choose Build, Build Solution.) The build step compiles the code and also packages it for use as a UWP app.
segment.target: (On the menu bar, choose Build, Build Solution.) The build step compiles the code and also packages it for use as a UWP app.

segment.source: After you build the project, you must deploy it.(On the menu bar, choose Build, Deploy Solution.) Visual Studio also deploys the project when you run the game from the debugger.
segment.target: After you build the project, you must deploy it.(On the menu bar, choose Build, Deploy Solution.) Visual Studio also deploys the project when you run the game from the debugger.

segment.source: After you deploy the project, pick the Marble Maze tile to run the game.
segment.target: After you deploy the project, pick the Marble Maze tile to run the game.

segment.source: Alternatively, from Visual Studio, on the menu bar, choose Debug, Start Debugging.
segment.target: Alternatively, from Visual Studio, on the menu bar, choose Debug, Start Debugging.

segment.source: Controlling the game
segment.target: Controlling the game

segment.source: You can use touch, the accelerometer, the Xbox 360 controller, or the mouse to control Marble Maze.
segment.target: You can use touch, the accelerometer, the Xbox 360 controller, or the mouse to control Marble Maze.

segment.source: Use the directional pad on the controller to change the active menu item.
segment.target: Use the directional pad on the controller to change the active menu item.

segment.source: Use touch, the A button, the Start button, or the mouse to pick a menu item.
segment.target: Use touch, the A button, the Start button, or the mouse to pick a menu item.

segment.source: Use touch, the accelerometer, the left thumbstick, or the mouse to tilt the maze.
segment.target: Use touch, the accelerometer, the left thumbstick, or the mouse to tilt the maze.

segment.source: Use touch, the A button, the Start button, or the mouse to close menus such as the high score table.
segment.target: Use touch, the A button, the Start button, or the mouse to close menus such as the high score table.

segment.source: Use the Start button or the P key to pause or resume the game.
segment.target: Use the Start button or the P key to pause or resume the game.

segment.source: Use the Back button on the controller or the Home key on the keyboard to restart the game.
segment.target: Use the Back button on the controller or the Home key on the keyboard to restart the game.

segment.source: When the high-score table is visible, use the Back button or Home key to clear all scores.
segment.target: When the high-score table is visible, use the Back button or Home key to clear all scores.

segment.source: Code conventions
segment.target: Code conventions

segment.source: The Windows Runtime is a programming interface that you can use to create UWP apps that run only in a special application environment.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime is a programming interface that you can use to create UWP apps that run only in a special application environment.

segment.source: Such apps use authorized functions, data types, and devices, and are distributed from the Windows Store.
segment.target: Such apps use authorized functions, data types, and devices, and are distributed from the Windows Store.

segment.source: At the lowest level, the Windows Runtime consists of an Application Binary Interface (ABI).
segment.target: At the lowest level, the Windows Runtime consists of an Application Binary Interface (ABI).

segment.source: The ABI is a low-level binary contract that makes Windows Runtime APIs accessible to multiple programming languages such as JavaScript, the .NET languages, and Visual C++.
segment.target: The ABI is a low-level binary contract that makes Windows Runtime APIs accessible to multiple programming languages such as JavaScript, the .NET languages, and Visual C++.

segment.source: In order to call Windows Runtime APIs from JavaScript and .NET, those languages require projections that are specific to each language environment.
segment.target: In order to call Windows Runtime APIs from JavaScript and .NET, those languages require projections that are specific to each language environment.

segment.source: When you call a Windows Runtime API from JavaScript or .NET, you are invoking the projection, which in turn calls the underlying ABI function.
segment.target: When you call a Windows Runtime API from JavaScript or .NET, you are invoking the projection, which in turn calls the underlying ABI function.

segment.source: Although you can call the ABI functions directly in C++, Microsoft provides projections for C++ as well, because they make it much simpler to consume the Windows Runtime APIs, while still maintaining high performance.
segment.target: Although you can call the ABI functions directly in C++, Microsoft provides projections for C++ as well, because they make it much simpler to consume the Windows Runtime APIs, while still maintaining high performance.

segment.source: Microsoft also provides language extensions to Visual C++ that specifically support the Windows Runtime projections.
segment.target: Microsoft also provides language extensions to Visual C++ that specifically support the Windows Runtime projections.

segment.source: Many of these language extensions resemble the syntax for the C++/CLI language.
segment.target: Many of these language extensions resemble the syntax for the C++/CLI language.

segment.source: However, instead of targeting the common language runtime (CLR), native apps use this syntax to target the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: However, instead of targeting the common language runtime (CLR), native apps use this syntax to target the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: The object reference, or hat (^), modifier is an important part of this new syntax because it enables the automatic deletion of runtime objects by means of reference counting.
segment.target: The object reference, or hat (^), modifier is an important part of this new syntax because it enables the automatic deletion of runtime objects by means of reference counting.

segment.source: Instead of calling methods such as AddRef and Release to manage the lifetime of a Windows Runtime object, the runtime deletes the object when no other component references it, for example, when it leaves scope or you set all references to nullptr.
segment.target: Instead of calling methods such as AddRef and Release to manage the lifetime of a Windows Runtime object, the runtime deletes the object when no other component references it, for example, when it leaves scope or you set all references to nullptr.

segment.source: Another important part of using Visual C++ to create UWP apps is the ref new keyword.
segment.target: Another important part of using Visual C++ to create UWP apps is the ref new keyword.

segment.source: Use ref new instead of new to create reference-counted Windows Runtime objects.
segment.target: Use ref new instead of new to create reference-counted Windows Runtime objects.

segment.source: For more info, see Type System (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more info, see Type System (C++/CX).

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: You only have to use and ref new when you create Windows Runtime objects or create Windows Runtime components.
segment.target: You only have to use and ref new when you create Windows Runtime objects or create Windows Runtime components.

segment.source: You can use the standard C++ syntax when you write core application code that does not use the Windows Runtime.
segment.target: You can use the standard C++ syntax when you write core application code that does not use the Windows Runtime.

segment.source: Marble Maze uses together with Microsoft::WRL::ComPtr to manage heap-allocated objects and minimize memory leaks.
segment.target: Marble Maze uses together with Microsoft::WRL::ComPtr to manage heap-allocated objects and minimize memory leaks.

segment.source: We recommend that you use ^ to manage the lifetime of Windows Runtime variables, ComPtr to manage the lifetime of COM variables (such as when you use DirectX), and std::std::shared\_ptr or std::unique\_ptr to manage the lifetime of all other heap-allocated C++ objects.
segment.target: We recommend that you use ^ to manage the lifetime of Windows Runtime variables, ComPtr to manage the lifetime of COM variables (such as when you use DirectX), and std::std::shared\_ptr or std::unique\_ptr to manage the lifetime of all other heap-allocated C++ objects.

segment.source: For more info about the language extensions that are available to a C++ UWP app, see Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).
segment.target: For more info about the language extensions that are available to a C++ UWP app, see Visual C++ Language Reference (C++/CX).

segment.source: Error handling
segment.target: Error handling

segment.source: Marble Maze uses exception handling as the primary way to deal with unexpected errors.
segment.target: Marble Maze uses exception handling as the primary way to deal with unexpected errors.

segment.source: Although game code traditionally uses logging or error codes, such as HRESULT values, to indicate errors, exception handling has two main advantages.
segment.target: Although game code traditionally uses logging or error codes, such as HRESULT values, to indicate errors, exception handling has two main advantages.

segment.source: First, it can make the code easier to read and maintain.
segment.target: First, it can make the code easier to read and maintain.

segment.source: From a code perspective, exception handling is a more efficient way to propagate an error to a routine that can handle that error.
segment.target: From a code perspective, exception handling is a more efficient way to propagate an error to a routine that can handle that error.

segment.source: The use of error codes typically requires each function to explicitly propagate errors.
segment.target: The use of error codes typically requires each function to explicitly propagate errors.

segment.source: A second advantage is that you can configure the Visual Studio debugger to break when an exception occurs so that you can stop immediately at the location and context of the error.
segment.target: A second advantage is that you can configure the Visual Studio debugger to break when an exception occurs so that you can stop immediately at the location and context of the error.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime also uses exception handling extensively.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime also uses exception handling extensively.

segment.source: Therefore, by using exception handling in your code, you can combine all error handling into one model.
segment.target: Therefore, by using exception handling in your code, you can combine all error handling into one model.

segment.source: We recommend that you use the following conventions in your error handling model:
segment.target: We recommend that you use the following conventions in your error handling model:

segment.source: Use exceptions to communicate unexpected errors.
segment.target: Use exceptions to communicate unexpected errors.

segment.source: Do not use exceptions to control the flow of code.
segment.target: Do not use exceptions to control the flow of code.

segment.source: Catch only the exceptions that you can safely handle and recover from.
segment.target: Catch only the exceptions that you can safely handle and recover from.

segment.source: Otherwise, do not catch the exception and allow the app to terminate.
segment.target: Otherwise, do not catch the exception and allow the app to terminate.

segment.source: When you call a DirectX routine that returns HRESULT, use the DX::ThrowIfFailed function.
segment.target: When you call a DirectX routine that returns HRESULT, use the DX::ThrowIfFailed function.

segment.source: This function is defined in DirectXSample.h.ThrowIfFailed throws an exception if the provided HRESULT is an error code.
segment.target: This function is defined in DirectXSample.h.ThrowIfFailed throws an exception if the provided HRESULT is an error code.

segment.source: For example, E\_POINTER causes ThrowIfFailed to throw Platform::NullReferenceException.
segment.target: For example, E\_POINTER causes ThrowIfFailed to throw Platform::NullReferenceException.

segment.target: When you use ThrowIfFailed, put the DirectX call on a separate line to help improve code readability, as shown in the following example.

segment.source: Although we recommend that you avoid the use of HRESULT for unexpected errors , it is more important to avoid the use of exception handling to control the flow of code.
segment.target: Although we recommend that you avoid the use of HRESULT for unexpected errors , it is more important to avoid the use of exception handling to control the flow of code.

segment.source: Therefore, it is preferred to use an HRESULT return value when necessary to control the flow of code.
segment.target: Therefore, it is preferred to use an HRESULT return value when necessary to control the flow of code.

segment.source: SAL annotations
segment.target: SAL annotations

segment.source: Use SAL annotations together with code analysis tools to help discover errors in your app.
segment.target: Use SAL annotations together with code analysis tools to help discover errors in your app.

segment.source: By using Microsoft source-code annotation language (SAL), you can annotate, or describe, how a function uses its parameters.
segment.target: By using Microsoft source-code annotation language (SAL), you can annotate, or describe, how a function uses its parameters.

segment.source: SAL annotations also describe return values.
segment.target: SAL annotations also describe return values.

segment.source: SAL annotations work with the C/C++ Code Analysis tool to discover possible defects in C and C++ source code.
segment.target: SAL annotations work with the C/C++ Code Analysis tool to discover possible defects in C and C++ source code.

segment.source: Common coding errors reported by the tool include buffer overruns, uninitialized memory, null pointer dereferences, and memory and resource leaks.
segment.target: Common coding errors reported by the tool include buffer overruns, uninitialized memory, null pointer dereferences, and memory and resource leaks.

segment.source: Consider the BasicLoader::LoadMesh method, which is declared in BasicLoader.h.
segment.target: Consider the BasicLoader::LoadMesh method, which is declared in BasicLoader.h.

segment.source: This method uses \_In\_ to specify that filename is an input parameter (and therefore will only be read from), \_Out\_ to specify that vertexBuffer and indexBuffer are output parameters (and therefore will only be written to), and \_Out\_opt\_ to specify that vertexCount and indexCount are optional output parameters (and might be written to).
segment.target: This method uses \_In\_ to specify that filename is an input parameter (and therefore will only be read from), \_Out\_ to specify that vertexBuffer and indexBuffer are output parameters (and therefore will only be written to), and \_Out\_opt\_ to specify that vertexCount and indexCount are optional output parameters (and might be written to).

segment.source: Because vertexCount and indexCount are optional output parameters, they are allowed to be nullptr.
segment.target: Because vertexCount and indexCount are optional output parameters, they are allowed to be nullptr.
